title: 111_s2129
content:
The Act may be cited as the "National Women's History Museum Act of 2009". It includes definitions. The Act, known as the "National Women's History Museum Act of 2009," provides definitions for key terms such as Administrator, CERCLA, Committees, Museum, and Property. The Property, located in the District of Columbia, consists of Squares 325 and 326 bounded by 12th Street, Independence Avenue, C Street, and the James Forrestal Building in Southwest Washington. It includes air rights, improvements, and appurtenances. The Property, located in the District of Columbia, consists of Squares 325 and 326 bounded by 12th Street, Independence Avenue, C Street, and the James Forrestal Building in Southwest Washington. It includes air rights, improvements, and appurtenances. SEC. 3. CONVEYANCE OF PROPERTY. The Administrator will convey the Property to the Museum with terms to protect US interests and further Act's purposes. An agreement must be made within 180 days, addressing mitigation of impacts, security concerns, and operational protocols. The Property will be purchased at fair market value determined by an independent appraisal. The appraiser must be mutually agreed upon by the Administrator and the Museum, with terms and conditions for the appraisal assignment also agreed upon. The Property will be purchased at fair market value determined by an independent appraisal. The appraisal should assume the Property is free of hazardous substances. The purchase price will be paid into the Federal Buildings Fund. The Administrator can use the proceeds for lawful purposes with notice to the Committees. The Property will be conveyed via a quit claim deed. The Property will be conveyed via a quit claim deed and dedicated for use as a national women's history museum for a 99-year period. If the property is not used for this purpose or construction does not begin within 5 years, it will revert to the United States without repayment. The Property will be conveyed for use as a national women's history museum for 99 years. The Administrator may enforce reversionary rights if the property is not used as intended. The conveyance must occur within 3 years of enactment, with possible extensions for the Museum to fulfill obligations. SEC. 4. ENVIRONMENTAL MATTERS.

The Administrator is authorized to contract with the Museum for environmental response actions on the Property. Costs incurred will be credited to the purchase price. This does not affect compliance with environmental laws.

SEC. 5. INCIDENTAL COSTS. The Museum is responsible for covering all costs related to complying with the Act, including studies, surveys, relocating tenants, and mitigating impacts on Federal buildings. Land use approvals are also addressed. The Administrator must cooperate with the Museum on zoning and land use matters related to the Property development, including consenting to zoning and permitting applications. Cooperation is subject to limitations, and the Administrator is not required to incur any costs. Consent is contingent on the Property being developed and operated in accordance with the Act. The Museum must submit annual reports to the Administrator and Committees detailing development and construction activities for 5 years after the Property conveyance or museum facility completion.
